claim.study_type: Observational (panel-data analysis using two-way fixed-effects regression models)

data.wave_or_subset: 18 OECD countries (Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, United States), 1970–2003
data.access_details: Publicly available through the OECD STAN database
data.notes: Outliers for seven observations (e.g., Norway 1999-2003, Belgium 1998-1999) were removed after Hadi robust outlier detection.

method.description: The study employs two-way fixed-effects regression models on a country-year panel of 18 OECD nations (1970–2003) to test the impact of national affluence, unbalanced productivity growth, and globalization on manufacturing employment. Models correct for serial correlation, spatial correlation, and heteroscedasticity using GLS (xtgls in Stata) and include lagged explanatory variables. Separate equations estimate indirect effects of trade on affluence and productivity growth.
steps: Assemble panel data from OECD STAN for manufacturing employment share and explanatory variables for 18 countries, 1970–2003.

Compute key variables: national affluence (per-capita income and higher-order terms), unbalanced productivity growth (difference in value added per worker between manufacturing and services, plus squared term), trade variables (North-South and North-North imports and exports as % of GDP), net outflow of direct investment, and unemployment (control).
Lag all explanatory variables by one year to model causal delay.
Conduct post-estimation tests (Wooldridge, modified Breusch-Pagan, modified Wald) to detect serial correlation, spatial correlation, and groupwise heteroscedasticity.
Fit two-way fixed-effects GLS models (xtgls) with five-year period dummies (1970–74 reference).
Apply Hadi robust outlier detection; drop seven identified outlying observations.
Estimate three main regression specifications: Model 1 (domestic causes), Model 2 (global causes), Model 3 (combined causes).
Estimate additional equations for indirect effects of trade on affluence and productivity growth; confirm limited error-term correlation and estimate each with FE-GLS.
Perform robustness check with 3SLS; verify results’ substantive consistency.
method.models: Two-way fixed-effects GLS panel regressions; additional FE-GLS equations; robustness check with 3SLS
method.outcome_variable: Relative manufacturing employment (manufacturing employment share of total employment)
method.independent_variables: National affluence (income per capita and higher-order terms), unbalanced productivity growth (and squared term), North-South imports (% GDP), North-South exports (% GDP), North-North imports/exports, net outflow of direct investment
method.tools_software: Stata (xtgls; post-estimation tests; Hadi outlier detection)

results.summary: All three factors—rising national affluence, unbalanced productivity growth, and globalization—significantly contributed to deindustrialization in advanced economies between 1970 and 2003. Affluence exerted the strongest influence, accounting for about one-third of the decline in manufacturing employment. North-South trade explained roughly one-quarter, while unbalanced productivity growth explained a little over one-seventh. Foreign direct investment was not a significant driver. Imports from the South displaced more jobs than exports created, and nonlinear relationships were found for both affluence and productivity growth.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Share of decline in manufacturing employment attributable to affluence
Share of decline in manufacturing employment attributable to North-South trade
Share of decline in manufacturing employment attributable to unbalanced productivity growth
